reviews.text: I had a 2 yr fixed mortgage with them. When coming to the end of the deal I decided to fix for another 2 yrs with them. I went for non advised as I thought it would be quicker and easier and last time I went the full advised route with them it dragged on for about 6 months before they were happy with all the info I provided them (inefficient, useless service). They wrote to me a very long winded confusing letter explaining everything. My deal was due to expire on 20th August so I made sure I got the signed agreement for my new deal back to them prior to this. Apparently this was not good enough and they needed it back before the end of the previous month in order for me to avoid going to SVR for a month. So my deal ended on the 20th and my new deal didnŠ—Èt start until the 1st of the following month. So for those 10 days they put me on SVR and charged me an additional Î£250 interest!!! I complained but apparently in the long winded confusing letter they sent me they basically have their arses covered so my complaint was not upheld. They gave me the usual take it to the ombudsman rubbish. Complete and utter rip off of a loyal customer. I was left completely skint for a month. There was absolutely no need for me to pay that interest to them. Unfortunately IŠ—Èm now tied into the gready ******** for another 2 yrs. AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE.

reviews.title: Punishing prudence – not the member-focused society they claim to be
reviews.text:
I approached Market Harborough with what any reasonable borrower would assume to be a simple, responsible, and forward-looking request: a conversation about short-term flexibility on a mortgage during a predictable, temporary lull in rental income. No arrears. No crisis. Just prudence - the kind of early engagement that every lender, regulator, and financial-wellbeing guide encourages.

What I encountered instead was a masterclass in how not to handle customers who are trying to stay ahead of the curve.

The initial silence was telling. Weeks passed with no acknowledgement, no holding reply, no sign that anyone was paying attention. For a building society that trades so heavily on mutuality, community values, and personal service, this felt like a curtain being pulled back to reveal a far more indifferent reality. When a reply finally arrived, it read like a template churned out after reluctantly dusting off the inbox: references to missing emails, apologies that rang hollow, and an invitation to resend everything as though the burden naturally sits with the customer rather than the institution.

The substance that followed was even more disheartening. Rather than engaging with the perfectly reasonable idea that a short, well-defined period might warrant proportionate, preventative support, the focus fixed instantly on “affordability assessments”, “financial difficulty”, and the need for detailed income-and-expenditure forms. Not as part of a tailored conversation, but as a default barrier to even discussing options.

In regulatory terms, what troubles me most is how this experience sits against the FCA’s own expectations of lenders. The FCA’s mortgage support guidance and Dear CEO communications on the cost of living make it clear that firms should offer prospective and tailored forbearance where customers indicate they are, or reasonably expect to be, in payment difficulty - including BEFORE any payment is actually missed – and that support should be appropriate to the customer’s individual circumstances rather than driven by rigid process. Layered on top of that, the Consumer Duty now requires firms to act to deliver good outcomes, avoid foreseeable harm and support customers in pursuing their financial objectives, not simply protect their own risk metrics. Against that backdrop, the slow response, the lack of meaningful engagement, and the default push into a full “hardship” framing with credit-file warnings - rather than a proportionate, constructive conversation about short-term flexibility – feels, in my view, out of step with both the letter and the spirit of what the FCA says good mortgage lenders should be doing.

This, for me, is where the experience strayed furthest from the principles MHBS claims to uphold. A customer taking proactive steps to plan carefully should not be met with suspicion, bureaucracy, and an implication that only hardship cases deserve attention. The FCA’s own guidance encourages lenders to support borrowers before difficulties escalate, to tailor their approach to individual circumstances, and to use discretion where a customer’s situation is temporary, logical, and easily resolved. Yet the impression here was of a lender more concerned with protecting its internal process map than with exercising common sense or acting in a member’s best interests.

The tone throughout was transactional, not mutual. Defensive, not supportive. A society that prides itself on doing things “the right way” should not make customers feel like an inconvenience for trying to engage early and responsibly. And it should certainly not treat every enquiry as though it must be funnelled into the same bureaucracy that applies to long-term, distressed borrowers.

In short, this experience left me with the view that MHBS struggles to live up to the values it promotes. If you are looking for a lender that genuinely listens, applies proportionality, and engages constructively with members who act in good faith, you may find the gulf between their marketing and their behaviour uncomfortably wide.

reviews.title: £100kdue back today (Friday) Nothing…
reviews.text:
£100k due back today (Friday) Nothing repaid. Very lucrative for MHBS to keep my funds over the weekend, and pay me nothing, Very cynical! Hopefully I will eventually get my funds back next week.
Best to avoid.

Now we know Friday maturity means MHBS keeps your funds over the weekend - convenient (for MHBS). So you lose two days interest on maturity.

Maturity on Friday in my book says repayment on Friday. I can make same day electronic payments so why can't MHBS? Cynical response, so you lose two days interest. 

So MHBS assert the maturity date is not exactly the maturity date, Convenient (for MHBS).

Excuses, excuses -free money for MHBS over the weekend - Great if you can get it at zero interest. 

Strangely even the current offerings mature on a Friday (What a coincidence!). YOU LOSE THE INTEREST TO WHICH YOU ARE ENTITLED!

Last B/S I will invest with in the future. I have not seen this cynical attitude with any of the many deposit takers I deal with.

reviews.text:
Visited the branch in Market Harborough as the account could only be opened in branch. Out of the way for me but they were extremely efficient. Three staff serving, and the lady (Claire) opened the account even though all three staff were busy at the counter. As existing customer she found my details. She asked if I had read how the account works online (I had) and provided the new account number and explained how to set up the standing order. I already had a regular saver with them, she understood that I didn't need everything explained. Very good perception of what the customer needs. Receipt given, no need for  passbook as withdrawals can't be made, and a copy of the key facts given.
A very good example of how to deal with a customer in a busy place. Well done to MHBS.

I did notice they had a machine inside that was used by others for deposits etc, freeing up time for cashiers. I noticed people were also able to deposit coins.

reviews.title: Good Service though disappointing communication
reviews.text:
Overall, the experience was a positive one, and I would have given it a 5 rating, except that, to my surprise and disappointment, my interest payments stopped before the date I expected them to stop. 
`it seemed I didn't understand that I was investing in a specific bond that had already been released for two months prior to my interest in it, and that it said so on the promotion. But in that case, why was my investment for 2 years accepted if it wasn't going to run for two years, but only 22 months? 

I have investments elsewhere which guided my actions, running for exactly the time I required. I didn't realise this was a specific product I had taken. 

Personally, once I had selected the time span, I would have done with seeing some kind of alert that told me that it would only run for 22 months, which then allowed me the option to change it. 

On top of that, the agent who was explaining today what happened to me kept telling me, often and condescendingly, that I should read everything carefully before I sign it! I was primarily focused on the time frame and the amount of interest at the time, and did not expect to be investing in anything that did not conform to the TWO years I selected.

I think all that is a pity because i did enjoy your service. I thought it was very professional, payments prompt, and well worth doing. It is just a shame that it did not end as I expected because, for me, it was silly to be allowed to invest in a product for 2 years when it didn't have two years left on it. 

What if there was only a year left on the bond? Would I still be able to invest in it for two years, while actually getting no interest for a year? 

I hope what I am saying is making sense, but this is not what I expected from a high street investment organisation, for Market Harborough to be getting the benefit of my money at the moment until October without me having any interest at all. 
That just doesn't seem right.
